awd_titl_txt: VOSS: Collaborative Research: Agency, Structure and Organization: Paths to Participation in Large-Scale Socio-Technical Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This project advances the study of socio-technical systems and social participation by investigating how system design, structure and agency are associated with different paths to participation in technology-mediated social participation (TMSP) systems. Online systems create organizational structural constraints and affordances by design, and therefore channel the potential for human agency -- roles, responsibilities and actions -- in ways that are not usually possible in the offline world. The project employs a mixed-methods design to examine collective behavior in different TMSP systems using longitudinal surveys and behavioral log data. In addition, this research includes a series of field experiments to test specific relationships between structural and organizational designs that facilitate collective outcomes and paths to participation.  The project?s intellectual merits include: (i) developing a rigorous understanding of how social participation changes over time as a result of systems design, socio-technical structure and human agency; (ii) extending the long history of social scientific theories and empirical research on collective behavior, motivation, and community participation in both laboratory and real world environments; and, (iii) developing specific recommendations and design guidelines for future TMSP and citizen science systems.

This project will foster increased public participation in TMSP systems, and increased scholarly awareness of technology-mediated collaborations and citizen science as effective research resources.  It will also encourage cross-disciplinary, cross-campus collaboration, by connecting scholars from a variety of disciplinary backgrounds, to study and advance TMSP research.  In addition, it will contribute to education, by providing opportunities for students to reason about, design and implement new TMSP systems to connect large numbers of distributed volunteers with social needs.

por.por_cntn:
In popular discourse, the online world is often treated as a fundamentally different place than the offline world. Discussions about risks and uncertainties on the internet tend to lean toward one of two extremes. At one end are optimistic utopians who point out that the internet provides unlimited opportunities to interact in large-scale conversations and e-commerce transactions without geographic restrictions. At the opposite extreme, others fear that the internet will become rampant with threats to security, privacy, and morality. Internet-based communication and social participation systems allows individuals to coordinate and collaborate in exciting new ways that are sometimes more efficient, and other times less so than traditional face-to-face interactions. 
In this multi-year project, we examined the different paths that individuals take as they participate in online systems. This cross-disciplinary, cross-campus collaboration brought together scholars and students from a variety of backgrounds and disciplines to study and advance our understanding of online social participation research. We know from a long history of prior research that the design of information technology systems significantly structures what we can do, where we can do it, and to whom access is given. In order to better understand the landscape of different roles and types of user participation, we examined several different online systems in our research. We studied very large and established systems such as Wikipedia and Airbnb, as well as newer systems such as online sharing websites, a local peer-to-peer network for single parents, micro-loan platforms, and platforms for distributing health information. We also used experimental methods to examine some of the specific ways that different types of shared information can influence or hinder the development of cooperation and trust between individuals. In each case, our over-arching research goal was to better understand the different ways that users engage with and use such systems over time. 
We used many different quantitative and qualitative methodologies to examine users' initial motivations when they first begin to use an online system, as well as how these motivations may change over time. Through our different studies, we find significant differences in key motivations such as reputation, enjoyment, and obligation on different types of user behaviors. In our research on local online exchange platforms, we identify a variety of challenges to integrating such platforms and explain the design implications that could aid others who attempt to introduce such platforms in their own local environments. Our research also shows both the value of financial assurances in online sharing economy systems for mitigating perceptions of risk, but we also show how these same financial assurances can actually work against the goals of fostering trust and reciprocity among users.
This project advanced the study social participation in online systems by investigating the interplay between human motivations, the design of online platforms, and social behavior from a variety of different angles. This grant enabled numerous published research papers, including two dissertations, that help develop a rigorous understanding of how social participation changes over time as a result of system design and human agency. Through our public talks, workshops, panel discussions and outreach to existing companies and organizations, we provided opportunities for students and researchers to reason about, design, and implement new ways to use socio-technical systems with emerging social needs.
